entry.title: Programming Languages Comparison: Recursion
entry.content:
Task

  • implement the factorial N = 1 if N <= 1, else N * factorial(n-1)

Solutions

C

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <stdlib.h>

int factorial(int n) {
    if (n == 1) {
        return 1;
    }
    else {
        return n * factorial(n-1);
    }
}

int main() {

    /* Enter your code here. Read input from STDIN. Print output to STDOUT */ 
    int n;
    scanf("%d", &n);
    printf("%d\n", factorial(n));

    return 0;
}

entry.title: Programming Languages Comparison: Array
entry.content:
Task

  • Reverse an array.

Solutions

C

#include <math.h>
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <assert.h>
#include <limits.h>
#include <stdbool.h>

int main(){
    int n; 
    scanf("%d",&n);
    int *arr = malloc(sizeof(int) * n);
    for(int arr_i = 0; arr_i < n; arr_i++){
       scanf("%d",&arr[arr_i]);
    }

#include <assert.h>

entry.title: Programming Languages Comparison: Class and Instance
entry.content:
Task

  • Write a class Person with an instance variable InitialAge with type int:
    • if initialAge <= 0, set age = 0;
    • if initialAge > 0, set age = initialAge.
  • Write a method amIOld:
    • if age < 13, print You are young.;
    • if age >= 13 and age < 18, print “You are a teenager.”;
    • if age > 18, print “You are old.”
  • Write a method yearPasses:
    • increases the instance variable age by 1.

Solutions

C

Not Valid

C++

using namespace std;
#include <iostream>

class Person{
public:
   int age ;
   Person(int initialAge);
   void amIOld();
   void yearPasses();
};
Person::Person(int initialAge){
  // Add some more code to run some checks on initialAge
    if (initialAge <= 0) {
        cout << "Age is not valid, setting age to 0." << endl;
        age = 0;
    }
    else {
        age = initialAge;
    }

}
void Person::amIOld(){
    // Do some computations in here and print out the correct statement to the console 
    if (age < 13) {
        cout << "You are young." << endl;
    }
    else if (age >= 13 && age < 18) {
        cout << "You are a teenager." << endl;
    }
    else {
        cout << "You are old." << endl;
    }
}


void Person::yearPasses(){
  // Increment the age of the person in here
  age += 1;

}

int main(){
    int T,age;
    cin>>T;
    for(int i=0;i<T;i++)
    {
        cin>>age;
        Person p(age);
        p.amIOld();
        for(int j=0;j<3;j++)
        {
            p.yearPasses();

        }
        p.amIOld();
        cout<<"\n";
    }
    return 0;
}

Java

public class Person {
    private int age;    

    public Person(int initialAge) {
        // Add some more code to run some checks on initialAge
        if (initialAge <= 0){
            System.out.println("Age is not valid, setting age to 0.");
            age = 0;
        }
        else {
            age = initialAge;
        }
    }

    public void amIOld() {
        // Write code determining if this person's age is old and print the correct statement:
        String output;
        if (age < 13) {
            output = "You are young.";
        } 
        else if (age >= 13 && age < 18) {
            output = "You are a teenager.";
        }
        else {
            output = "You are old.";
        }
        System.out.println(output);
    }

    public void yearPasses() {
        // Increment this person's age.
        age += 1;
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
            Scanner sc = new Scanner(System.in);
            int T = sc.nextInt();
            for (int i = 0; i < T; i++) {
                int age = sc.nextInt();
                Person p = new Person(age);
                p.amIOld();
                for (int j = 0; j < 3; j++) {
                    p.yearPasses();
                }
                p.amIOld();
                System.out.println();
        }
    }
}

entry.title: Programming Languages Comparison: Conditional Statements
entry.content:
Task

Given an integer n, perform the following conditonal actions:

  • if n is odd, print Weird;
  • if n is even, and in the inclusive range of 2 to 5, print Not Weird;
  • if n is even, and in the inclusive range of 6 to 20, print Weird;
  • if n is even, and greater than 20, print Not Weird.

Solutions

C

#include <math.h>
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <assert.h>
#include <limits.h>
#include <stdbool.h>

int main(){
    int N; 
    scanf("%d",&N);

    if (N%2==1){
        printf("Weird");
    }
    else{
        if (N%2==0 && N>=6 && N<=20){
            printf("Weird");
        }
        else{
            printf("Not Weird");
        }
    }

    return 0;
}
